{{short description|A Mesozoic land mass separated from Laramidia to the west by the Western Interior Seaway}} {{for|other uses of Appalachia|Appalachia (disambiguation)}} [[File:Cretaceous seaway.png|thumb|Appalachia, circa 100 mya]]
In the [[Mesozoic]] Era (252 to 66 million years ago) '''Appalachia''', named for the [[Appalachian Mountains]], was an island land mass separated from [[Laramidia]] to the west by the [[Western Interior Seaway]]. The seaway eventually shrank, divided across the [[The Dakotas|Dakotas]], and retreated towards the [[Gulf of Mexico]] and the [[Hudson Bay]]. This left the island masses joined in the continent of [[North America]] as the [[Rocky Mountains]] rose.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Weishampel|first1=David B.|last2=Young|first2=Luther|title=Dinosaurs of the East Coast|date=1996|publisher=Johns Hopkins University Press|location=Baltimore, MD.}}</ref>
From the [[Turonian]] to the end of the [[Campanian]] ages of the [[Late Cretaceous]], Appalachia was separated from the rest of North America. As the [[Western Interior Seaway]] retreated in the [[Maastrichtian]], Laramidia and Appalachia eventually connected.<ref name=stanley>{{cite book |last=Stanley |first=Steven M. |title=Earth System History |location=New York |publisher=W.H. Freeman and Company |year=1999 |isbn=0-7167-2882-6 |pages=487–489}}</ref> Because of this, its [[fauna]] was isolated, and developed very differently from the [[tyrannosaur]], [[ceratopsian]], [[pachycephalosaur]] and [[Ankylosauria|ankylosaur]] dominated fauna of the western part of North America, known as "[[Laramidia]]". Due to numerous undiscovered fossiliferous deposits and due the fact that half of Appalachia's fossil formations being destroyed by the [[Pleistocene ice age]],<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Braun|first1=Duane D.|title=Glacial and periglacial erosion of the Appalachians|journal=Geomorphology|date=September 1989|volume=2|issue=1–3|pages=233–256 |doi=10.1016/0169-555X(89)90014-7|bibcode=1989Geomo...2..233B}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Pielou|first1=E. C.|title=After the Ice Age: The Return of Life to Glaciated North America|date=1 December 1992|publisher=University Of Chicago Press|location=Chicago, IL|pages=376}}</ref> little is known about Appalachia, with exception of plant life and the insects trapped in [[New Jersey amber|amber from New Jersey]]. Many of the various fossil formations not destroyed by the Pleistocene ice age still remain elusive to the field of paleontological study. In addition, due to a lack of interest in Appalachia, many fossils that have been found in Appalachia lie unstudied and remain in the inaccurate genera to which they were assigned in the days of [[Edward Drinker Cope|E.D. Cope]] and [[O.C. Marsh]]. However, the area has seen a bit of a resurgence of interest due to several discoveries made in the past few years.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Uren|first1=Adam|title=Dinosaurs in Minnesota: Fossil claw found in Iron Range has scientists excited|url=http://bringmethenews.com/2015/10/10/dinosaurs-in-minnesota-fossil-claw-found-in-iron-range-has-scientists-excited/|accessdate=10 October 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Sawyer|first1=Liz|title=Fossil adds to evidence of dinosaurs in Minnesota|url=http://www.startribune.com/fossil-adds-to-evidence-of-dinosaurs-in-minnesota/331496711/|publisher=Star Tribune|accessdate=8 October 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Fossil finds behind N.J. strip mall causing excitement|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/drexel-university-fossil-finds-behind-new-jersey-strip-mall-causing-excitment/|website=CBS Evening News|accessdate=16 November 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Anonymous|title=Rare fossil of a horned dinosaur found from ‘lost continent’|url=http://www.bath.ac.uk/news/2015/11/30/dinosaur-evolution/|website=University of Bath News|publisher=University of Bath|accessdate=30 November 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Anderson|first1=Natali|title=Eotrachodon orientalis: New Duck-Billed Dinosaur Species Discovered|url=http://www.sci-news.com/paleontology/eotrachodon-orientalis-new-duck-billed-dinosaur-species-03591.html|website=Science News.com|publisher=Science News|accessdate=26 January 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Griffiths|first1=Sarah|title=Dinosaurs suffered from arthritis too! 70 million-year-old hadrosaur fossil shows its joints were covered in bony growths|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sciencetech/article-3720034/Dinosaurs-suffered-arthritis-70-million-year-old-hadrosaur-fossil-shows-joints-covered-bony-growths.html|website=Dailymail.co.uk|accessdate=2 August 2016}}</ref> As mentioned earlier, not much is known about Appalachia, but some fossil sites, such as the [[Navesink Formation]],<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Kennedy|first1=William J.|last2=Landman|first2=Neil H.|last3=Cobban|first3=William Aubrey|last4=Johnson|first4=R.O.|title=Additions to the ammonite fauna of the Upper Cretaceous Navesink Formation of New Jersey. American Museum Novitates|journal=American Museum Novitates|date=13 December 2000|pages=31|url=http://digitallibrary.amnh.org/handle/2246/2008}}</ref> [[Ellisdale Fossil Site]],<ref>{{cite book|last1=Gallagher|first1=W.B.|title=When Dinosaurs Roamed New Jersey|date=1997|publisher=Rutgers University Press|location=New Brunswick, NJ}}</ref> [[Mooreville Chalk Formation]], [[Demopolis Chalk Formation]], [[Black Creek Group]] and the [[Niobrara Formation]],<ref>{{cite web|title=Oceans of Kansas|url=http://oceansofkansas.com/}}</ref> together with ongoing research in the area,<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Brownstein|first1=Chase|title=The biogeography and ecology of the Cretaceous non-avian dinosaurs of Appalachia|journal=Palaeontologia Electronica|date=17 January 2018|volume=21|issue=1.5a|pages=1–56|doi=10.26879/801|url=http://palaeo-electronica.org/content/2018/2123-appalachia-biogeography|accessdate=15 February 2018}}</ref> have given us a better look into this forgotten world of [[paleontology]].
==Fauna==
===Dinosaurs===
In Late Cretaceous North America, the dominant predators were the [[tyrannosaurs]], huge predatory [[theropods]] with proportionately massive heads built for ripping flesh from their prey. Tyrannosaurs were the dominant predators in Appalachia too, but rather than the massive [[Tyrannosauridae]], like ''[[Gorgosaurus]]'', ''[[Albertosaurus]]'' and ''[[Lythronax]]'',<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Loewen|first1=Mark A.|last2=Irmis|first2=Randall B.|last3=Setrich|first3=Joseph J. W.|last4=J. Currie|first4=Philip|last5=D. Sampson|first5=Scott|title=Tyrant Dinosaur Evolution Tracks the Rise and Fall of Late Cretaceous Oceans|journal=PLOS One|date=6 November 2013|volume=8|issue=11|page=14|doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0079420|bibcode=2013PLoSO...879420L}}</ref> which evolved around the same time that the Western Interior Seaway had fully separated Laramida from Appalachia, the smaller [[Dryptosaurus|dryptosaur]]s were the top predators of Appalachia. Rather than developing the huge heads and massive bodies of their kin, dryptosaurs had more in common with the basal tyrannosaurs like ''[[Dilong (dinosaur)|Dilong]]'' and ''[[Eotyrannus]]'', having long arms with three fingers,<ref>{{cite web|last1=Switek|first1=Brian|title=Dryptosaurus’ Surprising Hands|url=http://www.smithsonianmag.com/science-nature/dryptosaurus-surprising-hands-28909886/?no-ist|website=Smithsonian Magazine|accessdate=11 July 2011}}</ref> and were not as large as the largest tyrannosaurids. Three genera of valid Appalachian tyrannosaurs are known, ''[[Dryptosaurus]]'', ''[[Appalachiosaurus]]'', and the recently discovered ''[[Teihivenator]]'' while other indeterminate fossils lie scattered throughout most of the southern United States like Georgia, North Carolina, and South Carolina. These fossiled teeth possibly belong to a species of ''Appalachiosaurs'' or an undescribed species of a new tyrannosaur.<ref>{{cite journal |first1=Yun |last1=Chan-gyu |year=2017 |title=Teihivenator gen. nov., a new generic name for the Tyrannosauroid Dinosaur "Laelaps" macropus (Cope, 1868; preoccupied by Koch, 1836)|journal=Journal of Zoological and Bioscience Research |volume=4 |url= https://www.journalzbr.com/index.php/jzbr/article/view/71/0}}</ref><ref name="Carr et al 2005">{{cite journal |doi=10.1671/0272-4634(2005)025[0119:ANGASO]2.0.CO;2 |year=2005 |volume=25 |pages=119–43 |title=A new genus and species of tyrannosauroid from the Late Cretaceous (Middle Campanian) Demopolis Formation of Alabama |journal=Journal of Vertebrate Paleontology |last1=Carr |first1=Thomas D |last2=Williamson |first2=Thomas E |last3=Schwimmer |first3=David R }}</ref> There is also the possibility of a fourth tyrannosaur known from Applachia known as ''[[Diplotomodon]]'', but this is highly unlikely seeing how the genus is considered to be dubious. Various [[Ornithomimidae|ornithomimid]] bones, such as ''[[Coelosaurus antiquus|Coelosaurus]]'', have also been reported from Appalachia from Missouri, Mississippi, Alabama, Georgia and as far north in states like Maryland, New Jersey and Delaware, but it is now believed that some of these are the bones of juvenile dryptosaurs while others belong to various undescribed species of ornithomimids. The case of ''[[Arkansaurus]]'' is such an example of indeterminate fossils being discovered to be dating back to the Early Cretaceous. The dryptosaurs weren't the only predatory dinosaurs in Appalachia. Indeterminate [[Dromaeosauridae|dromaeosaurine]] fossils and teeth, most closely matching those of ''[[Saurornitholestes]]'',<ref>{{cite web|last1=Kiernan,|first1=Caitlin R.|last2=Schwimmeri|first2=David R.|title=First Record of a Velociraptorine Theropod (Tetanurae, Dromaeosauridae) from the Eastern Gulf Coastal United States|url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/277954680_First_Record_of_a_Velociraptorine_Theropod_Tetanurae_Dromaeosauridae_from_the_Eastern_Gulf_Coastal_United_States|website=ResearchGate|publisher=Journal of the Delaware Valley Paleontological Society: 89–93.|accessdate=7 May 2004}}</ref> have also been unearthed in Appalachia as well; mostly in the southern states like Missouri, North Carolina, South Carolina, Alabama, Mississippi and Georgia.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Westfall|first1=Aundrea|title=Dromaeosaurs|url=http://www.encyclopediaofalabama.org/article/h-3684|website=Encyclopedia of Alabama|publisher=Encyclopedia of Alabama|accessdate=18 May 2016}}</ref> Finds from the Campanian Tar Heel Formation in North Carolina indicate that there may have been dromaeosaurids of considerable size; intermediate between genera such as ''Saurornitholestes'' and ''[[Dakotaraptor]]''. Though known only from teeth, the discovery indicates large dromaeosaurids were part of Appalachia's fauna.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.cretres.2018.07.006 |title=A giant dromaeosaurid from North Carolina |journal=Cretaceous Research |year=2018 |last1=Brownstein |first1=Chase }}</ref> Along with the dromaeosauridae remains, tyrannosauroidea and possible ornithomimid remains have been unearthed in Missouri as well.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Fix|first1=Michael F.|title=Dinosauria and Associated Vertebrate Fauna of the Late Cretaceous Chronister Site of Southeast Missouri|url=https://gsa.confex.com/gsa/2004NC/finalprogram/abstract_71688.htm|publisher=Geological Society of America|accessdate=1 April 2004}}</ref>
Another common group, arguably the most wide spread species in the area,<ref>{{cite web|last1=King Jr.|first1=David T.|title=Late Cretaceous Dinosaurs of the Southeastern United States|url=http://www.auburn.edu/~kingdat/dinosaur_webpage.htm|website=www.aubrun.edu|publisher=Auburn University Press|accessdate=14 September 2016}}</ref> of Appalachian dinosaurs were the [[Hadrosauroidea]],<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Colbert|first1=Edwin H.|title=A Hadrosaurian Dinosaur from New Jersey|journal=Proceedings of the Academy of Natural Sciences of Philadelphia|date=1948|volume=100|pages=23–37|jstor=4064414}}</ref> which is now considered to be their "ancestral homeland"; eventually making their way to Laramidia, [[Asia]],<ref name=Kundurosaurus>{{Cite journal | last1 = Godefroit | first1 = P. | last2 = Bolotsky | first2 = Y. L. | last3 = Lauters | first3 = P. | editor1-last = Joger | editor1-first = Ulrich | title = A New Saurolophine Dinosaur from the Latest Cretaceous of Far Eastern Russia | doi = 10.1371/journal.pone.0036849 | journal = PLoS ONE | volume = 7 | issue = 5 | pages = e36849 | year = 2012 | pmid = 22666331| pmc = 3364265| bibcode = 2012PLoSO...736849G }}</ref><ref name=GBA03>{{cite journal |last=Godefroit |first=Pascal |author2=Bolotsky, Yuri |author3= Alifanov, Vladimir |year=2003 |title=A remarkable hollow-crested hadrosaur from Russia: an Asian origin for lambeosaurines |journal=Comptes Rendus Palevol |volume=2 |pages=143–151 |doi=10.1016/S1631-0683(03)00017-4 |issue=2}}</ref><ref name=Getal00>{{cite journal |last=Godefroit |first=Pascal |author2=Shuqin Zan |author3= Liyong Jin |year=2000 |title=''Charonosaurus jiayinensis'' n. g., n. sp., a lambeosaurine dinosaur from the Late Maastrichtian of northeastern China |journal=Comptes Rendus de l'Académie des Sciences, Série IIA |volume=330 |issue=12 |pages=875–882 |doi=10.1016/S1251-8050(00)00214-7|bibcode = 2000CRASE.330..875G }} </ref><ref name=Bolotskyetal1991>Bolotsky, Y.L. & Kurzanov, S.K. 1991. [The hadrosaurs of the Amur Region.] In: [''Geology of the Pacific Ocean Border'']. Blagoveschensk: Amur KNII. 94-103. [In Russian]</ref><ref name=Godefroitetal2004 >{{cite journal|last=Godefroit|first= P.|last2= Bolotsky|first2= Y. L.|last3= Van Itterbeeck|first3= J. |date=2004|title=The lambeosaurine dinosaur Amurosaurus riabinini, from the Maastrichtian of Far Eastern Russia|journal= Acta Palaeontologica Polonica|volume= 49 |issue=4|pages=585–618}}</ref> [[Europe]],<ref name=CPSW97>{{cite journal | last1 = Casanovas | first1 = M.L | last2 = Pereda-Suberbiola | first2 = X. | last3 = Santafé | first3 = J.V. | last4 = Weishampel | first4 = D.B. | year = 1999 | title = First lambeosaurine hadrosaurid from Europe: palaeobiogeographical implications | url = | journal = Geological Magazine | volume = 136 | issue = 2| pages = 205–211 | doi=10.1017/s0016756899002319| bibcode = 1999GeoM..136..205C }}</ref><ref name=XPSetal09>{{cite journal |last=Pereda-Suberbiola |first=Xabier |author2=José Ignacio Canudo|author3=Penélope Cruzado-Caballero|author4=José Luis Barco|author5=Nieves López-Martínez|author6=Oriol Oms|author7= José Ignacio Ruiz-Omeñaca |year=2009 |title=The last hadrosaurid dinosaurs of Europe: A new lambeosaurine from the Uppermost Cretaceous of Aren (Huesca, Spain) |journal=Comptes Rendus Palevol |volume=8 |issue=6 |pages=559–572 |doi=10.1016/j.crpv.2009.05.002}}</ref> [[South America]]<ref name=Willinakaqe>{{Cite journal|author=Rubén D. Juárez Valieri|author2= José A. Haro|author3= Lucas E. Fiorelli |author4= Jorge O. Calvo |year=2010 |title=A new hadrosauroid (Dinosauria: Ornithopoda) from the Allen Formation (Late Cretaceous) of Patagonia, Argentina |url=http://www.macn.secyt.gov.ar/investigacion/descargas/publicaciones/revista/12/rns_vol12-2_217-231.pdf |journal=Revista del Museo Argentino de Ciencias Naturales n.s. |volume=11 |issue=2 |pages=217–231 |doi= }}</ref> and [[Antarctica]]<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Case|first1=Judd A.|last2=Martin|first2=James E.|last3=Chaney|first3=Dan S.|last4=Regurero|first4=Marcelo|last5=Marenssi|first5=Sergio A.|last6=Santillana|first6=Sergio M.|last7=Woodburne|first7=Michael O.|title=The First Duck-Billed Dinosaur (Family Hadrosauridae) from Antarctica|journal=Journal of Vertebrate Paleontology|date=25 September 2000|volume=20|issue=3|pages=612–614|jstor=4524132|doi=10.1671/0272-4634(2000)020[0612:tfdbdf]2.0.co;2}}</ref> where they diversified into the [[lambeosaurine]] and [[saurolophine]] dinosaurs, though some of the primitive hadrosaurs<ref name=FDV09>{{cite journal |last=Dalla Vecchia |first=F. M. |year=2009 |title=''Tethyshadros insularis'', a new hadrosauroid dinosaur (Ornithischia) from the Upper Cretaceous of Italy |journal=Journal of Vertebrate Paleontology |volume=29 |issue=4 |pages=1100–1116 |doi=10.1671/039.029.0428}}</ref> were still present until the end of the Mesozoic.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Lund|first1=Eric K.|last2=Gates|first2=Terry A.|title=A Historical and Biogeographical Examination of Hadrosaurian Dinosaurs|date=January 2006|url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/228761051_A_HISTORICAL_AND_BIOGEOGRAPHICAL_EXAMINATION_OF_HADROSAURIAN_DINOSAURS}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Kaye|first1=John M.|last2=Russell|first2=Dale.|title=The oldest record of hadrosaurian dinosaurs in North America|journal=Journal of Paleontology|date=1973|pages=91–93}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|title=Research team identifies rare dinosaur from Appalachia|date=21 January 2016|url=http://artsandsciences.fsu.edu/News-and-Publications/News/Research-team-identifies-rare-dinosaur-from-Appalachia|accessdate=11 September 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Lull|first1=Richard S.|last2=Wright|first2=Nelda E.|title=Hadrosaurian dinosaurs of North America|journal=Geological Society of America|date=1942|volume=Geological Society of America Special Papers|issue=40|pages=1–272}}</ref> While the fossil record shows a staggering variety of hadrosaur forms in Laramidia, hadrosaur remains for Appalachia show less diversity due to the relative uncommon number of fossil beds. However, many hadrosaurs are known from Appalachia, such as ''[[Claosaurus]]'', ''[[Eotrachodon]]'', ''[[Lophorhothon]]'', ''[[Hypsibema crassicauda]]'', ''[[Hypsibema missouriensis]]'', and ''[[Hadrosaurus]]''. These hadrosaurs from Appalachia seem to be closely related to the crestless hadrosaurs of Laramidia like ''[[Gryposaurus]]'' and ''[[Edmontosaurus]]'', despite the fact that they are not considered to be [[saurolophine]]s. ''Claosaurus'' is known from a specimen which floated into the Interior Seaway and was found in Kansas, might also be from Appalachia, since it was found closer to the Appalachia side of the seaway and is unknown from Western North America. Hadrosaur remains have even been found in [[Iowa]], though in fragmentary remains,<ref>{{cite web|last1=Witzke|first1=Brain J.|title=Dinosaurs in Iowa|url=http://www.iihr.uiowa.edu/igs/dinosaurs-in-iowa/|website=Iowa Geological Society|publisher=Iowa Department of Natural Resources, University of Iowa|accessdate=12 August 2014}}</ref> [[Tennessee]], most notably from the [[Coon Creek Formation]].<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Byran|first1=Jonathan R.|last2=Frederick|first2=Daniel L.|last3=Schwimmer|first3=David R.|last4=Siesser|first4=William G.|title=First dinosaur record from Tennessee: a Campanian hadrosaur|journal=Journal of Paleontology|date=July 1991|volume=65|issue=4|pages=696–697|url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/264495718_First_dinosaur_record_from_Tennessee_a_Campanian_hadrosaur|accessdate=11 September 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Markin|first1=Walter L.|last2=Gibson|first2=Michael A.|title=Discovery of a Second Hadrosaur From the Late Cretaceous Coon Creek Formation, West Tennessee|journal=Geological Society of America Abstracts with Programs|date=3 November 2010|volume=42|issue=5|page=631}}</ref> ''Hypsibema crassicauda'',<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Cope | first1 = E.D. | year = 1869 | title = Remarks on ''Eschrichtius polyporus'', ''Hypsibema crassicauda'', ''Hadrosaurus tripos'', and ''Polydectes biturgidus'' | url = | journal = Proceedings of the Academy of Natural Sciences of Philadelphia | volume = 21 | issue = | pages = 191–192 }}</ref> over fifty feet long, was one of the largest eastern hadrosaurs, outgrowing some of more derived western hadrosaurs like ''[[Lambeosaurus]]'' and ''[[Saurolophus]]''. The genus likely took the environmental niche occupied by large [[sauropod]]s in other areas, possibly grown to colossal sizes to that of ''[[Magnapaulia]]''<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Albert|first1=Prieto-Marquez|last2=Luis|first2=M. Chiappe|last3=Shantanu|first3=H. Joshi|title=The Lambeosaurine Dinosaur Magnapaulia laticaudus from the Late Cretaceous of Baja California, Northwestern Mexico|journal=PLoS ONE|date=12 June 2012|volume=7|issue=6|pages=29|url=http://journals.plos.org/plosone/article?id=10.1371/journal.pone.0038207|accessdate=11 September 2016|doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0038207|pmid=22719869|pmc=3373519|bibcode=2012PLoSO...738207P}}</ref> and ''[[Shantungosaurus]]''.<ref>{{cite web|author=Chase|title=Antediluvian Beasts of the East: Hypsibema crassicauda|url=https://thetetanuraeguy.wordpress.com/2015/06/22/antediluvian-beasts-of-the-east-hypsibema-crassicauda/|website=thetetanuraeguy.wordpress.com|accessdate=22 June 2015}}</ref> ''Hypsibema missouriensis'', was another large species of hadrosaur, but it grew up to 45 to 49 feet, which wasn't as large as ''Hypsibema crassicauda''. When it was first discovered in 1945, it was mistaken for a species of sauropod.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Gilmore|first1=Charles W.|last2=Stewart|first2=Dan R.|title=A New Sauropod Dinosaur from the Upper Cretaceous of Missouri|journal=Journal of Paleontology|date=January 1945|volume=19|issue=1|pages=23–29|jstor=1299165}}</ref> Hypsibema missouriensis, possibly even all of the other hadrosaurs living on Appalachia, had serrated teeth for chewing the vegetation in the area.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bcmnh.org/fossilprep.html|website=Bollinger County Museum of Natural History|title=Welcome to the Fossil Prep Lab!}}</ref> Indeterminate [[lambeosaurinae]] remains, mostly similar to ''[[Corythosaurus]]'', have been reported from [[Navesink Formation|New Jersey's Navesink Formation]] and [[Nova Scotia, Canada]]. It cannot yet be explained how lambeosaurines might have reached Appalachia though some have theorized that a land bridge must have formed some time during the [[Campanian]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Chase|title=A response to The Tetrapod Zoology Podcast #45: Why Lambeosaurines did, in fact, persist into the Maastrichtian|url=https://thetetanuraeguy.wordpress.com/2015/07/30/a-response-to-the-tetrapod-zoology-podcast-45-why-lambeosaurines-did-in-fact-persist-into-the-maastrichtian/|website=An Odyssey of Time|publisher=Anonymous|accessdate=30 July 2015}}</ref>
The [[nodosaurids]], a group of large, herbivorous [[Ankylosauria|armored dinosaur]]s resembling [[armadillo]]s, are another testament to Appalachia's difference from Laramidia. During the early Cretaceous, the nodosaurids prospered and were one of the most wide spread dinosaurs throughout North America. However, by the latest Cretaceous, nodosaurids were scarce in western North America,<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Bakker|first1=Robert T.|title=Review of the Late Cretaceous nodosauroid Dinosauria: Denversaurus schlessmani, a new armor-plated dinosaur from the Latest Cretaceous of South Dakota, the last survivor of the nodosaurians, with comments on Stegosaur-Nodosaur relationships|journal=Hunteria|date=1988|volume=1|issue=3|pages=1–23}}</ref> limited to forms like ''[[Edmontonia]]'', ''[[Denversaurus]]'' and ''[[Panoplosaurus]]''; perhaps due to competition from the [[ankylosauridae]]; though they did thrive in isolation, most notably in Appalachia, as mentioned earlier and in the case of ''[[Struthiosaurus]]'',<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Garcia | first1 = G. | last2 = Pereda-Suberbiola | first2 = X. | year = 2003 | title = A new species of ''Struthiosaurus'' (Dinosauria: Ankylosauria) from the Upper Cretaceous of Villeveyrac (southern France) | url = | journal = Journal of Vertebrate Paleontology | volume = 23 | issue = 1| pages = 156–165 | doi=10.1671/0272-4634(2003)23[156:ansosd]2.0.co;2}}</ref> Europe as well. Nodosaurid [[scutes]] have been commonly found in eastern North America, while fossil specimens are very rare. Often the findings are not diagnostic enough to identify the species, but the remains attest to a greater number of these armored dinosaurs in Appalachia. Multiple specimens have been unearthed in [[Kansas]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Approximate location of Smoky Hill Chalk nodosaur remains.|url=http://oceansofkansas.com/Niobrarasaurus/county.jpg|accessdate=13 September 2016}}</ref> in the Niobrara Formation, Alabama in [[Ripley Formation]],<ref>{{cite web|last1=Bruns|first1=Michael E.|title=New Appalachian Armored Dinosaur Material (Nodosauridae, Ankylosauria) From the Maastrichtian Ripley Formation of Alabama|url=https://gsa.confex.com/gsa/2016SE/webprogram/Paper273236.html|website=The Geological Society of America|publisher=The Geological Society of America|accessdate=1 April 2016}}</ref> Mississippi, Delaware, Maryland and New Jersey, possibly belonging to a multitude of different species.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Ebersole|first1=Jun|title=Nodosaur|url=http://www.encyclopediaofalabama.org/article/h-3553|website=Encyclopedia of Alabama|publisher=Encyclopedia of Alabama|accessdate=18 May 2016}}</ref> Five possible and best known examples of Appalachian nodosaurids, from both the early and late Cretaceous period, include ''[[Priconodon]]'', ''[[Propanoplosaurus]]'', ''[[Niobrarasaurus]]'',<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Everhart|first1=Michael J.|last2=Hamm|first2=Shawn A.|title=A new nodosaur specimen (Dinosauria: Nodosauridae) from the Smoky Hill Chalk (Upper Cretaceous) of western Kansas|journal=Transactions of the Kansas Academy of Science|date=January 2005|volume=108|issue=1&2|pages=15–21|doi=10.1660/0022-8443(2005)108[0015:ANNSDN]2.0.CO;2|year=2005}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Carpenter|first1=Kenneth|last2=Everhart|first2=Michael J.|title=Skull of the ankylosaur Niobrarasaurus coleu (Ankylosauria: Nodosauridae) from the Smoky Hill Chalk (Coniacian) of western Kansas|journal=Transactions of the Kansas Academy of Science|date=April 2007|volume=110|issue=1 & 2|pages=1–9 |doi=10.1660/0022-8443(2007)110[1:SOTANC]2.0.CO;2|year=2007}}</ref> ''[[Silvisaurus]]''<ref name="Eaton1961">{{cite journal | last1 = Eaton | first1 = T.H. | last2 = Jr | first2 = | year = 1960 | title = A new armored dinosaur from the Cretaceous of Kansas | url = http://hdl.handle.net/1808/3799 | journal = The University of Kansas Paleontological Contributions: Vertebrata | volume = 8 | issue = | pages = 1–24 }}</ref> and possibly ''[[Hierosaurus]]'',<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.2475/ajs.s4-27.159.250 |title=A new armored saurian from the Niobrara |journal=American Journal of Science |issue=159 |pages=250–2 |year=1909 |last1=Wieland |first1=G. R }}</ref> though its validity is disputed. Just like the ''Claosaurus'' specimen, it is possible that the specimens of ''Niobrarasaurus'', ''Silvisaurus'' and ''Hierosaurus'' floated into the Interior Seaway from the east, since these two species of nodosaurids were discovered in the famous [[chalk formations]]<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Carpenter|first1=Kenneth|last2=Dilkes|first2=David|last3=Weishampel|first3=Dave|title=The Dinosaurs of the Niobrara Chalk Formation (Upper Cretaceous, Kansas)|journal=Journal of Vertebrate Paleontology|date=June 1995|volume=15|issue=2|pages=275–297 |doi=10.1080/02724634.1995.10011230 }}</ref> of Kansas and are not known from any location from Western North America. Kansas was also a part of Appalachia when the other parts were covered by oceans, which were a part of the Western Interior Seaway.
While remains of the advanced ceratopsians, most notably the [[centrosaurines]] and [[chasmosaurines]]<ref>{{cite web|author=|title=Amazing horned dinosaurs unearthed on 'lost continent'; New discoveries include bizarre beast with 15 horns|url=https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2010/09/100922121943.htm|website=ScienceDaily|publisher=University of Utah|accessdate=22 September 2010}}</ref> which were very common in Laramidia during this timeperiod, where not found in Appalachia, the [[leptoceratopsids]] somehow managed to inhabit that location.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Anonymous|title=A new Leptoceratopsid Ceratopsian From Campanian Cretaceous Appalachia|url=http://thedragonstales.blogspot.com/2015/09/a-new-leptoceratopsid-ceratopsian-from.html|website=The Dragon's Tales|accessdate=14 September 2015}}</ref> A [[Campanian]]-era [[Leptoceratopsidae|leptoceratopsid]] [[ceratopsian]] has been found in the [[Tar Heel Formation]], marking the first discovery of a ceratopsian dinosaur in the Appalachian zone. This specimen bears a uniquely long, slender and downcurved upper jaw, suggesting that it was an animal with a specialised feeding strategy, yet another example of speciation on an island environment.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Longrich | first1 = Nicholas R. | year = 2016| title = A ceratopsian dinosaur from the Late Cretaceous of eastern North America, and implications for dinosaur biogeography | journal = Cretaceous Research | volume = 57 | issue = | pages = 199–207 | doi=10.1016/j.cretres.2015.08.004}}</ref> Recently, a ceratopsian teeth were unearthed in Mississippi's Owl Creek Formation,<ref name="http://www.wlox.com/story/32562654/paleontologists-make-big-dinosaur-discovery-in-mississippi">{{cite web|last1=Brantley|first1=Mary Grace|url=http://www.msnewsnow.com/story/32562654/paleontologists-make-big-dinosaur-discovery-in-mississippi|title=Paleontologists make big dinosaur discovery in Mississippi|website=MSNewsNow|accessdate=14 September 2016}}</ref> which have been dated to be 67 million years old.<ref name="http://www.wapt.com/news/mississippi/rare-dinosaur-tooth-found-in-mississippi/40929616">{{cite web|last1=Fleet|first1=Micah|title=Rare dinosaur tooth found in Mississippi|website=www.wapt.com|url=http://www.wapt.com/article/rare-dinosaur-tooth-found-in-mississippi/2099081|publisher=16 WAPT News|accessdate=14 September 2016}}</ref> While leptoceratopids remains, the few that have been discovered in recent years, have been unearthed in the southern part of Appalachia, they appear to be completely absent from the northern part of Appalachia, states like New Jersey, Delaware and Maryland. Suggesting the idea, proposed by paleontologist David R. Schwimmer, that there was a possible providence during the Late Cretaceous.<ref>{{cite web|last1=David R.|first1=Schwimmer|title=Was There a Southeastern Dinosaur Province in the Late Cretaceous?|url=https://gsa.confex.com/gsa/2016SE/webprogram/Paper271634.html|website=1 April 2016|publisher=Geological Society of America|accessdate=12 September 2016}}</ref>
Several bird remains are known from Appalachian sites, most of them [[sea birds]] like [[Hesperornithes]], ''[[Ichthyornis]]'', [[Enantiornithes]] like ''[[Halimornis]]'' and ''[[Ornithurae]]s'' like ''[[Apatornis]]'' and ''[[Iaceornis]]''. Of particular interest are possible [[Lithornithidae|lithornithid]] remains in [[New Jersey]], arguably one of the best records<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Olson|first1=Storrs L.|last2=Parris|first2=David C.|title=The Cretaceous Birds of New Jersey|journal=Smithsonian Contributions to Paleobiology|date=1987|volume=63|pages=1–25|url=https://repository.si.edu/bitstream/handle/10088/6539/VZ_198_New_Jersey_Cretaceous_hi_res.pdf?sequence=1}}</ref> for Cretaceous birds<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Wetmore|first1=Alexander|title=The Age of the Supposed Cretaceous Birds from New Jersey|journal=The Auk|date=April 1930|volume=47|issue=2|pages=186–188|jstor=4075921|doi=10.2307/4075921}}</ref> as some specimens were preserved in the [[greensand]]s<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Baird|first1=Donald|title=Age of Fossil Birds from the Greensands of New Jersey|journal=The Auk|date=April 1967|volume=84|issue=2|pages=260–262|jstor=4083191|doi=10.2307/4083191}}</ref> in the area,<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=P_TB72RBLLMC&pg=PA27&lpg=PA27&dq=lithornithid+new+jersey&source=bl&ots=Gt8A2jGBY1&sig=Knq-jH_2d96CD3sxapkMstx-X00&hl=pt-PT&sa=X&ei=9KcdVceDA8PsUsrZgMgI&ved=0CB8Q6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=lithornithid%20new%20jersey&f=false Palaeogene Fossil Birds]</ref><ref>[http://escholarship.org/uc/item/6cm4v7h4 A lithornithid (Aves: Palaeognathae) from the Paleocene (Tiffanian) of southern California]</ref> which would represent a clear example of [[palaeognath]] [[Neornithes]] in the Late Cretaceous. However, this issue is still under debate.
===Non-dinosaur herpetofauna===
Through the [[Ellisdale Fossil Site]], a good picture of Appalachia's non-dinosaurian fauna is present. Amidst [[lissamphibia]]ns, there is evidence for [[Sirenidae|sirenids]] (including the large ''[[Habrosaurus]]''), the batrachosauroidid salamander ''[[Parrisia]]'', [[Hylidae|hylids]], possible representatives of ''[[Eopelobates]]'' and ''[[Discoglossus]]'', showing close similarities to European faunas, but aside from ''[[Habrosaurus]]'' (which is also found on Laramidia) there is a high degree of endemism, suggesting no interchanges with other landmasses throughout the Late Cretaceous.<ref>Le Loeuff, J., 1991, The Campano-Maastrichtian vertebrate faunas of southern Europe and their relationship with other faunas in the world; paleobiogeographic implications. Cretaceous Res., 12(2), pp:93–114.</ref> There is also a high degree of endemism in regards for its reptilian fauna: among squamates, the [[Teiidae|teiid]] Prototeius is exclusive to the landmass, and native representatives of [[Iguanidae]], [[Helodermatidae]], and [[Necrosauridae]]. Amidst [[turtles]], ''[[Adocus]]'', ''[[Apalone]]'', and ''[[Bothremydidae|Bothremys]]'' are well represented, the latter in particular more common in appalachian sites than laramidian ones. The five local [[crocodilian]] genera, ''[[Deinosuchus]]'', ''[[Thoracosaurus]]'',<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Troxell|first1=Edward L.|title=Thoracosaurus, A Cretaceous Crocodile|journal=American Journal of Science|date=September 1925|volume=5|issue=10|pages=219–233|url=http://www.ajsonline.org/content/s5-10/57/219.full.pdf+html|accessdate=11 September 2016}}</ref> ''[[Eothoracosaurus]]'',<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Brochu|first1=Christopher A.|title=A new Late Cretaceous gavialoid crocodylian from eastern North America and the phylogenetic relationships of thoracosaurs|journal=Journal of Vertebrate Paleontology|date=5 January 2004|volume=24|issue=3|pages=610–633 |doi=10.1671/0272-4634(2004)024[0610:ANLCGC]2.0.CO;2|year=2004}}</ref>''[[Leidyosuchus]]'', ''[[Borealosuchus]]'',<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Brochu|first1=Christopher A.|last2=Parris|first2=David C.|last3=Grandstaff|first3=Barbara Smith|last4=Denton Jr.|first4=Robert K.|last5=Gallagher|first5=William B.|title=A new species of Borealosuchus (Crocodyliformes, Eusuchia) from the Late Cretaceous–early Paleogene of New Jersey|journal=Journal of Vertebrate Paleontology|date=12 January 2012|volume=32|issue=1|pages=105–116 |doi=10.1080/02724634.2012.633585}}</ref> are well established in Laramidia as well, probably indicative of their ocean crossing capacities. ''Deinosuchus'',<ref>{{cite book|last1=Schwimmer|first1=David R.|title=King of the Crocodylians: The Paleobiology of Deinosuchus|date=12 June 2002|publisher=Indiana University Press|location=Bloomington, IN|pages=240}}</ref> being one of the largest crocodilians of the fossil record,<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Erickson|first1=Gregory M.|last2=Brochu|first2=Christopher A.|title=How the 'terror crocodile' grew so big|journal=Nature|date=18 June 1999|volume=398|issue=6724|pages=205–206|doi=10.1038/18343|bibcode=1999Natur.398..205E}}</ref> was an [[apex predator]] that did prey on the dinosaurs<ref>{{cite web|last1=Handwerk|first1=Brain|title=Feces, Bite Marks Flesh Out Giant Dino-Eating Crocs|url=http://news.nationalgeographic.com/news/2010/03/100323-giant-croc-crocodile-dinosaurs-deinosuchus-feces-poop/|website=National Geographic News|accessdate=25 March 2010}}</ref> in the area, the same case applies for Laramidia as well,<ref>{{cite journal|last1=RIVERA-SYLVA|first1=Héctor E.|last2=FREY|first2=Eberhard|last3=GUZMÁN-GUTIÉRREZ|first3=José Rubén|title=Evidence of predation on the vertebra of a hadrosaurid dinosaur from the Upper Cretaceous (Campanian) of Coahuila, Mexico|journal=Carnets de Géologie|date=2009|pages=1–7|url=http://paleopolis.rediris.es/cg/CG2009_L02/}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Rivera-Sylva|first1=Hector E.|last2=W.E. Hone|first2=David|last3=Dodson|first3=Peter|title=Bite marks of a large theropod on an hadrosaur limb bone from Coahuila, Mexico|date=2012|volume=64|issue=1|pages=157–161|url=http://scielo.unam.mx/pdf/bsgm/v64n1/v64n1a12.pdf}}</ref> despite the fact that the majority of its diet consisted of turtles<ref>{{cite web|title=Illustration of the hypothetical Deinosuchus-on-pleurodire bite, based on the position of typical bite marks. Wide gape biting would allowthe posterior teeth to do most of the crushing, without putting the sharperanterior teeth in danger of fracture. With this bite pattern, there would alsobe numerous marks on turtle neurals and approximately equal numbers ofcarapace and plastron bite traces. In addition, various regions of the turtleshell would receive varying pressures and depth of bite marks. Drawing byRon Hirzel, reproduced from Schwimmer (2002).|url=https://www.researchgate.net/profile/David_Schwimmer/publication/264495658/viewer/AS:126899678355456@1407266649131/background/4.png}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Milan|first1=J|last2=Lucas|first2=Spencer G.|last3=Lockley|first3=M G|last4=Schwimmer|first4=David R.|title=Bite Marks of the Giant Crocodylian Deinosuchus on Late Cretaceous (Campanian) Bones|date=January 2010|url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/264495658_BITE_MARKS_OF_THE_GIANT_CROCODYLIAN_DEINOSUCHUS_ON_LATE_CRETACEOUS_CAMPANIAN_BONES}}</ref> and [[sea turtles]].<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Harrell|first1=Samantha D.|last2=Schwimmer|first2=David R.|title=Coprolites of Deinosuchus and other crocodylians from the Upper Cretaceous of western Georgia, USA|date=2010|pages=1–7|url=http://csuepress.columbusstate.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1219&context=bibliography_faculty}}</ref> [[Pterosaur]] fossils, mostly similar to ''[[Pteranodon]]'' and ''[[Nyctosaurus]]'', have been unearthed in Georgia,<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Schwimmer|first1=David R.|last2=Padian|first2=Kevin|last3=Woodhead|first3=Alfred B.|title=First Pterosaur Records from Georgia: Open Marine Facies, Eutaw Formation (Santonian)|jstor=1304987|publisher=Journal of Paleontology|volume=59|pages=674–676}}</ref> Alabama<ref>{{cite web|last1=Westfall|first1=Aundrea|title=Pterosaurs|website=Encyclopedia of Alabama|url=http://www.encyclopediaofalabama.org/article/h-3664|accessdate=26 August 2016}}</ref> and Delaware.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Bairid|first1=Donald|last2=Galton|first2=Peter M.|title=Pterosaur Bones from the Upper Cretaceous of Delaware|jstor=4522837|publisher=Journal of Paleontology|volume=1|pages=67–71}}</ref> On a similar note, [[Azhdarchidae|azhdrachid]] remains have been reported in Tennessee.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Gibson|first1=Michael A.|title=Review of Vertebrate Diversity n the Coon Creek Formation Lagerstätte (Late Cretaceous) of Western Tennessee|url=https://gsa.confex.com/gsa/2008SC/finalprogram/abstract_136826.htm|publisher=Geological Society of America|accessdate=31 March 2008}}</ref> No fossilized remains of [[snakes]] have been discovered in Appalachia during the Cretaceous period, only being found in Laramidia.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Holman|first1=J. Alan|title=Fossil Snakes of North America: Origin, Evolution, Distribution, Paleoecology|date=22 May 2000|publisher=Indiana University Press|location=Bloomington, Indiana|pages=376}}</ref>
===Mammals===
Several types of [[mammals]]<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Baird|first1=D.|last2=Krause|first2=D.W.|title=Late Cretaceous mammals east of the North American Western Interior Seaway|journal=Journal of Paleontology|date=1 May 1979|volume=53|issue=3|url=http://jpaleontol.geoscienceworld.org/content/53/3/562|accessdate=13 September 2016}}</ref> are also present on [[Ellisdale Fossil Site|Ellisdale]] and in the both of the [[Carolinas]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Denton Jr.|first1=Robert K.|title=Late Cretaceous Mammals of the Carolinas|url=https://gsa.confex.com/gsa/2016SE/webprogram/Paper273384.html|website=gsa.confex.com|publisher=The Geological Society of America|accessdate=1 April 2016}}</ref> The most common are [[ptilodontoidea]]n [[multituberculates]], such as ''[[Mesodma]]'', ''[[Cimolodon]]'' and a massively sized species. The sheer diversity of species on the landmass, as well as the earlier appearance compared to other Late Cretaceous locales, suggests that ptilodontoideans evolved in Appalachia.<ref>[https://gsa.confex.com/gsa/2014SE/webprogram/Paper235341.html Late Cretaceous Multituberculates of the Carolinas: My...What Big Teeth You Have!]</ref><ref name="S. Grandstaff, D. C 1992">{{cite journal | last1 = Grandstaff | first1 = B. S. | last2 = Parris | first2 = D. C. | last3 = Denton Jr | first3 = R. K. | last4 = Gallagher | first4 = W. B. | year = 1992 | title = Alphadon (Marsupialia) and Multituberculata (Allotheria) in the Cretaceous of eastern North America | url = | journal = Journal of Vertebrate Paleontology | volume = 12 | issue = 2| pages = 217–222 | doi=10.1080/02724634.1992.10011450}}</ref> [[Metatherian]] are also known, including an [[alphadon]]tid,<ref name="S. Grandstaff, D. C 1992"/> a [[Stagodontidae|stagodontid]],<ref>Denton, R. K. Jr., & O’Neill, R. C., 2010, A New Stagodontid Metatherian from the Campanian of New Jersey and its implications for a lack of east-west dispersal routes in the Late Cretaceous of North America. ''Jour. Vert. Paleo.'' 30(3) supp.</ref> and an [[Herpetotheriidae|herpetotheriid]].<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Martin | first1 = JE | last2 = Case | first2 = JA | last3 = Jagt | first3 = JWM | last4 = Schulp | first4 = AS | last5 = Mulder | first5 = EWA | year = 2005 | title = A new European marsupial indicates a Late Cretaceous high latitude dispersal route | url = | journal = Mammal. Evol. | volume = 12 | issue = 3–4| pages = 495–511 | doi=10.1007/s10914-005-7330-x}}</ref> Unlike ptilodontoideans, metatherians show a lesser degree of endemism, implying a degree of interchange with Laramidia and Europe.

Channel 132 (SD) | cable serv 1 = [[StarHub TV]] ([[Singapore]]) | cable chan 1 = Channel 118 (SD) | online serv 1 = | online chan 1 = }} '''Astro Warna''' is a 24-hour television network in Malaysia. Launched on 1 June 2009, this channel airs local and international [[comedy]] programmes. It is broadcast on the [[Astro (satellite television)|Astro]] [[satellite television]] platform as part of the Mustika Pack via Channel 132. Before launching Astro Warna, formerly all local comedy programmes were shown on either [[Astro Ria]] or [[Astro Prima]]. After launching Astro Warna, almost all local comedy programmes shown on their existing Malay channels moved to Astro Warna, although some programs such as [[Raja Lawak Astro]] continued to be shown on Astro Prima for its fourth and fifth season, before moving to Astro Warna in its sixth season. '''Astro Warna HD''' is the simulcast HD version of Astro Warna. It was launched on 11 May 2017 for all Astro customers that subscribed to HD service with Mustika Pack on channel 124. Previously, their programmes on HD were shown on [[Mustika HD|Astro Mustika HD]], leaving the latter to focus on their other two channels.http://astrobyondinfo.weebly.com/home/astro-warna-is-now-in-hd Astro Mustika HD has rebranding to [[Astro Citra|Astro Citra HD]] on 1 October 2018, but, they moved to channel 126 in this situation. ==Programmes== ===Local programmes=== * ''Spontan'' * ''Gerabak'' * ''Ten Ten Ten'' * ''Ek Eleh'' * ''Impak Minima'' * ''Kampung Jaguh'' * ''Tetangga'' * ''Elak Elak'' * ''Maharaja Lawak'' * ''Raja Lawak S6'' * ''Raja Lawak S7'' * ''Redah Kasi Pecah'' * ''Redah Kasi Pecah Ekstravaganza'' * ''Betul ke Bohong?'' * ''Super Spontan'' * ''Super Spontan 2013'' * ''Karoot Komedia'' * ''Karoot Komedia X S1'' * ''Karoot Komedia X S2'' * ''Maharaja Lawak Mega 2011'' * ''Maharaja Lawak Mega 2012'' * ''Sembang Teh Tarik'' * ''Wartawan Kampung'' * ''Maharaja Lawak Mega 2013'' * ''Super Spontan 2014'' * ''Anugerah Lawak Warna'' * ''Sembang Teh Tarik S2'' * ''Keluarga Iskandar S2'' (also aired on [[Mustika HD|Astro Mustika HD]]) * ''Maharaja Lawak Mega 2014'' (also aired on [[Mustika HD|Astro Mustika HD]] and [[Astro Prima]]) * ''Ini Malam Kita Punya'' (Malaysian version of ''See U Tonight'' format) ===Foreign programmes=== * ''[[The Simpsons]]'' * ''[[Malcolm in the Middle]]'' * ''Family No. 1'' * ''[[Yes, Dear]]'' * ''[[Dharma & Greg]]'' * ''[[Sabrina the Teenage Witch]]'' * ''Tetangga (Seasons 1 & 2)'' * ''Zero Downpayment'' * ''Erlin Montel'' * ''2 x 5 Dol (Seasons 1 & 2)'' * ''Fiesta Komedi'' * ''Kadir & Kadir'' * ''CMYK'' ==References== {{Reflist}} ==See also== * [[Astro Citra]] {{Malaysia TV}} {{Asia-tv-stub}} [[Category:Astro television channels]]

{{primary sources |date=April 2018}} '''bibliotek.dk''' is a [[Denmark|Danish]] [[Internet]] service that allows for search for materials in public Danish libraries. It is a library catalog.
Search targets include [[book]]s, [[newspaper]] and [[Academic journal|journal]] articles, [[LP (format)|LP]] records, [[DVD]], [[CD-ROM]]s, etc. Material from Danish libraries can be requested and sent to the local library.
[[Dansk BiblioteksCenter]] (DBC), a state-owned limited liability company, develops and maintains the service.
==See also== *[[Danish National Library Authority]]
==External links== * [http://bibliotek.dk/ Bibliotek.dk] * [http://www.dbc.dk/english/?searchterm=english Dansk BiblioteksCenter (DBC)] official site in English
[[Category:Bibliographic databases and indexes]] [[Category:Government databases in Denmark]]
{{Denmark-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox organization |name = Center for International Policy |image_border = |size = |alt = |abbreviation = CIP |formation = 1975 |type = Public Policy [[Think Tank]] |purpose = Demilitarization, National Security, Progressive Foreign Policy |headquarters = 2000 M Street NW, Suite 720 |location = [[Washington, D.C.]], United States |leader_title = President & CEO |leader_name = [[Salih Booker]] |budget= Revenue: $2,579,579
Expenses: $4,602,711
([[Fiscal year|Fiscal year 2014]]){{cite web | url=http://www.charitynavigator.org/index.cfm?bay=search.summary&orgid=5436 | title=Center for International Policy | date= | website=Charity Navigator | accessdate=13 April 2016 }} |homepage = {{URL|www.internationalpolicy.org}} }} The '''Center for International Policy''' ('''CIP''') is a non-profit [[Left-wing politics|left of center]]https://www.internationalpolicy.org [[public policy]] research and advocacy [[think tank]] with offices in [[Washington, D.C.]] and [[New York City]]. It was founded in 1975 in response to the [[Vietnam War]]/American War. The Center describes its mission as promoting "cooperation, transparency and accountability in global relations. Through research and advocacy, our programs address the most urgent threats to our planet: war, corruption, inequality and climate change." {{cite web |title=About Us |publisher=Center for International Policy |url=http://ciponline.org/aboutus.htm |date=26 May 2010 |accessdate=2010-06-22}} The Center is the parent organization for a variety of projects, including [[Security Assistance Monitor]], [[Win Without War]] and [[the Arms & Security Project]]. It also has collaborated with the [[Washington Office on Latin America]] and the Latin America Working Group to publish the ''Just the Facts'' website. Several prominent individuals serve as senior fellows and board members with CIP, including former Costa Rican president [[Óscar Arias Sánchez]], UN ambassador [[Dessima Williams]], [[Michael D. Barnes|Michael Barnes]], and [[Matthew Hoh]]. __TOC__ == History == === 1970s === The Center was founded in 1975 under the fiscal sponsorship of the [[Fund for Peace]] by activists, including [[William Goodfellow (executive)|Bill Goodfellow]] and then-retired US foreign service official Donald Ranard, who served as the Center's first Executive Director. During its first years, the Center focused its work on Asia, especially United States foreign policy towards [[South Korea]] and its relationships with the [[Park Chung-hee]]-led government. In 1976, Ranard testified to [[United States Congress|Congress]] on human rights violations in South Korea and the role of South Korean lobbyists in Washington.{{cite web |title=Donald L. Ranard, 73, U.S. Aide Who Disclosed Seoul's Lobbying |publisher=New York Times |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/01/obituaries/donald-l-ranard-73-us-aide-who-disclosed-seoul-s-lobbying.html |date=1 August 1990 |accessdate=2011-08-10}} In 1978, the Center established an Indochina Program, which advocated the normalization of diplomatic relations with [[Vietnam]], [[Laos]], and [[Cambodia]]; the program was closed 11 years later in 1989. In the mid-1970s, while at the time also co-chairs of the Center's Board, [[United States House of Representatives|US Representatives]] [[Donald M. Fraser|Donald Fraser]] and [[Tom Harkin]] introduced legislation that incorporated foreign countries' human rights records into consideration of security and economic aid.{{cite web |title=Assistant Secretary Michael Posner: On The Release Of The 2010 Human Rights Reports |publisher=United States Department of State |url=http://www.humanrights.gov/2011/04/11/assistant-secretary-michael-h-posner-remarks-to-the-press-on-the-release-of-the-2010-country-reports-on-human-rights-practices/ |date=11 April 2011 |accessdate=2011-08-11}} === 1980s === During the 1980s, CIP campaigned in support of the [[Contadora Group]] and the subsequent [[Esquipulas Peace Agreement]]. After [[South Africa]] received a loan from the [[International Monetary Fund]] in 1983, the Center began a campaign that pushed for provisions that prohibited the US representative to the IMF to support loans to countries that practice [[apartheid]].{{cite web |title=Center for International Policy (15) |publisher=[[African Activist Archive]] |url=http://africanactivist.msu.edu/browse_results.php?category=organization&field=organization&member=Center_for_International_Policy |date=11 August 2011 |accessdate=2011-08-11}} The Center continued its work with research into labor practices and economic impacts of apartheid in South Africa. === 1990s === In 1990, the Center established a joint program with the [[Costa Rica]]-based [http://www.arias.or.cr/ Arias Foundation], founded by [[Óscar Arias]]. The organisation's new President, [[Robert White (ambassador)|Robert White]], also worked extensively with [[Haiti]]an President [[Jean-Bertrand Aristide]] during his exile in Washington in the 1990s.{{cite web |title=Aristide Raised Haiti's Hopes, Then Shattered Them |publisher=New York Times |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2004/03/01/international/americas/01ARIS.html?pagewanted=all |date=1 March 2004 |accessdate=2011-08-11}} [[Wayne Smith (diplomat)|Wayne Smith]] joined the Center in 1991 to establish the '''Cuba program''', working towards the normalisation of relations between the United States and [[Cuba]]. In the mid-1990s, [[Adam Isacson]] established the Latin American Security program, which still operates today. The program campaigned against the militarisation of [[Plan Colombia]] and supporting the movement of funds to programs for judicial reforms and economic development. In June 1999, the program led the first ever congressional delegation to meet with insurgent leaders inside the territory they controlled.{{cite press release |title=Celebrating 25 Years of Citizen Diplomacy |publisher=Center for International Policy |year=2000}} === 2000s === [[Clarissa Segun]] and [[Paul Olweny]], leaders for the '''Demilitarization for Democracy''' project, joined the Center in 2000. The project campaigned for diplomatic aid and [[United Nations]] [[peacekeeping]].{{cite web |title=U.N. Peacekeeping |publisher=New York Times |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2000/06/19/opinion/l-un-peacekeeping-801259.html |date=19 June 2000 |accessdate=2011-08-11}} The project eventually closed in 2006. [[Sarah Stephens]] worked on Cuba policy, joining the Center in 2001 with the '''Freedom to Travel''' project. She left CIP in 2006 and then launched the Center for Democracy in the Americas (CDA).{{cite web |title=Staff - Sarah Stephens |publisher=Center for Democracy in the Americas |url=http://www.democracyinamericas.org/about-cda/staff/ |year=2011 |accessdate=2011-08-11}} In 2003, then-President [[Robert White (ambassador)|Robert White]] established a program focused on governmental [[corruption]] in [[Central America]], specifically [[illegal logging]] in [[Honduras]]. Former [[Washington Post]] foreign correspondent [[Selig S. Harrison|Selig Harrison]] joined CIP in the same year to head the Center's '''Asia program''' which focused on [[North Korea]] and the [[Indian subcontinent]]. With the publishing of his book ''Capitalism's Achilles Heel: Dirty Money and How to Renew the Free-Market System'' (Wiley & Sons, 2005), CIP senior fellow [[Raymond W. Baker|Raymond Baker]] founds [[Global Financial Integrity]] (GFI), a non-profit, research and [[advocacy group|advocacy organisation]] focused on the role of [[illicit financial flows]]. In June 2007, the '''Americas Program''' joined CIP after the dissolution of the [[International Relations Center]].{{cite web |title=IRC's History |publisher=International Relations Center |url=http://irc-online.org/ |date=1 June 2007 |accessdate=2011-08-11 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://swap.stanford.edu/20100323140146/http%3A//www.irc%2Donline.org/ |archivedate=23 March 2010 |df= }} The Americas Program continues as the TransBorder Project and the Americas Project today. == Current Programs == The Center currently operates six programs including [[Win Without War]], [[Security Assistance Monitor]], [[the Arms &n Security Project]] among others. In its capacity, the Center also fiscally sponsors the environmental protection organization, Mighty Earth. === Win Without War === Win Without War is coalition that promotes a more progressive national security strategy. Formed in 2002 to lead the first national campaign against the war in Iraq and the policies of the Bush/Cheney Administration, Win Without War continues as a core program of CIP directed by [[Stephen Miles]]. Current projects include efforts to bring American troops home from Afghanistan, rein in spending at the Pentagon, prevent nuclear escalation with North Korea, bring awareness to US involvement in Yemen. === Security Assistance Monitor === Led by director [[Colby Goodman]], Security Assistance Monitor tracks and analyzes U.S. security and defense assistance programs worldwide. By informing policymakers, media, scholars, NGOs and the public in the United States and abroad about trends and issues related to U.S. foreign security assistance, their aim is to enhance transparency and promote greater oversight of U.S. military and police aid, arms sales and training. The SAM database compiles all publicly available data on U.S. foreign security assistance programs worldwide from 2000 to the present. Collected from a wide range of government documents, the database provides detailed numbers on U.S. arms sales, military and police aid and training programs. Users can search these numbers by country, region, program and assistance type. === Arms & Security Project === The Arms and Security Project engages in media outreach and public education aimed at promoting reforms in U.S. policies on nuclear weapons, military spending and the arms trade. It seeks to advance the notion that diplomacy and international cooperation are the most effective tools for protecting the United States. According to program director [[William D. Hartung]], "the use of military force is largely irrelevant in addressing the greatest dangers we face, from terrorism, to nuclear proliferation, to epidemics of disease, to climate change, to inequities of wealth and income. The allocation of budgetary resources needs to be changed to reflect this reality." Hartung's research is most frequently sited in publications such as [[The Hill (newspaper)|the Hill]], [[Defense News]], [[the Washington Post]] among others. === Full list of current CIP programs === -[[Win Without War]] -[[Security Assistance Monitor]] -[[Arms & Security Project]] -Cuba Program -[[Americas Program]] -[[Global Progressive Hub]] -[[Avoided Deforestation Partners]] -[[Mighty Earth]] (fiscally sponsored) == References == {{primary sources|date=February 2011}} {{reflist|2}} == External links == * [http://www.internationalpolicy.org/ Center for International Policy] [[Category:Peace organizations]] [[Category:Foreign policy and strategy think tanks in the United States]] [[Category:Non-profit organizations based in Washington, D.C.]] [[Category:Think tanks established in 1975]]

The '''Cercle artistique de Luxembourg''' or '''CAL''', was founded in 1893 as ''Cercle artistique luxembourgeois'', is an association which brings together artists of all types with a view to supporting artistic work and art education in the [[Luxembourg|Grand Duchy of Luxembourg]].<ref name=Lexikon>"Cercle artistique de Luxembourg", ''Luxemburger Lexikon'', Editions Guy Binsfeld, Luxembourg, 2006. {{De icon}}</ref><ref>[http://www.cal.lu/apropos.php "A propos du CAL"], ''Cercle artistique de Luxembourg''. {{Fr icon}}</ref>
The founding members were [[Michel Engels]] and Pierre Blanc and Franz Heidenstein who was the association's first president (1893–99). Since 1896, the ''Salon du CAL'' exhibition has been held each year.<ref name=Lexikon/> Among Luxembourg's prominent artists who exhibited at the salon were [[Dominique Lang]], [[Emile Kirscht]] and [[Michel Stoffel]] and the sculptor [[Claus Cito]].<ref name="MediArt">[http://www.mediart.lu/fileadmin/H2O/Michel_Stoffel.pdf "Michel Stoffel"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110722160412/http://www.mediart.lu/fileadmin/H2O/Michel_Stoffel.pdf |date=2011-07-22 }}, ''MediArt.lu''. {{Fr icon}} Retrieved 30 January 2011.</ref><ref>[http://www.cal.lu/apropos.php Georgette Bisdorff, "Claus Cito"], ''Ons stad'', No 70, 2002. {{Fr icon}} Retrieved 30 January 2011.</ref>
==See also== *[[Art of Luxembourg]] *[[Iconomaques]]
== External links == *[http://www.cal.lu/apropos.php Cercle artistique de Luxembourg website]
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Luxembourgian art]] [[Category:Cultural organisations based in Luxembourg]] [[Category:Arts organizations established in 1893]] [[Category:1890s establishments in Luxembourg]]
{{Luxembourg-stub}}

{{Politics of the European Union}} The '''Directorate-General for Taxation and Customs Union''' is a [[Directorate-General]] of the [[European Commission]]. The DG Taxation and Customs manages, defends and develops the customs union as a vital part of protecting the external borders of the [[European Union]]. It also co-ordinates taxation policy across the European Union.
==Structure==
The Directorate-General is organised into five directorates:<ref>{{cite web |url=http://ec.europa.eu/taxation_customs/resources/documents/common/about/structure/organi_en.pdf |title=Organisation Chart - Taxation and Customs Union Directorate General (01/06/2010) |publisher=[[European Commission]] |accessdate=2010-06-23 }}</ref> *Directorate R: Resources *Directorate A: Customs Policy, Legislation, Tariff *Directorate B: Security & Safety, Trade Facilitation & International coordination *Directorate C: Indirect Taxation and Tax Administration *Directorate D: Direct taxation, Tax Coordination, Economic Analysis and Evaluation
==See also== *[[Customs union]] *[[Taxation]] *[[Single European Act]] *[[General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade]] (GATT)
==References== <references/>
==External links== *[http://ec.europa.eu/taxation_customs/index_en.htm Directorate-General for Taxation and Customs Union] *[http://ec.europa.eu/ecip European Customs Information Portal (ECIP)] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20121026015416/http://ec.europa.eu/taxation_customs/dds2/taric/taric_consultation.jsp?Lang=en&redirectionDate=20100623 TARIC - Online customs tariff database] *[http://ec.europa.eu/taxation_customs/common/elearning/general_overview/index_en.htm eLearning courses in Customs and Taxation]
{{Eu-directorates-general}}
[[Category:Directorates-General in the European Commission|Taxation and Customs Union]] [[Category:International taxation]] [[Category:Tax organizations]]
{{EU-stub}}

{{Infobox World's Fair | box_width = | class = Specialized | image = | image_width = | caption = | year = 1981 | name = Expo 81 | motto = Hunting, fishing, and man in society | building = [[International Fair Plovdiv]] | area = | invent = | visitors = | organized = | cnt = | org = | biz = | country = [[Bulgaria]] | city = [[Plovdiv]] | venue = | coord = | cand = | award = | open = June 14 1981 | close = July 12 1981 | prevexpo = [[Expo '75]] | prevcity = [[Okinawa]] | nextexpo = [[1982 World's Fair]] | nextcity = [[Knoxville]] | suppl = Universal | prevsuppl = [[Expo '70]] | prevsupcity = [[Osaka]] | nextsuppl = [[Seville Expo '92]] | nextsupcity = [[Seville]] | simuni = | simspe = | simhor = | simoth = | website = }} The '''Plovdiv International Exhibition of 1981''' was regulated by the [[Bureau International des Expositions]] and took place from June 14 to July 12, 1981 in [[Plovdiv]], [[Bulgaria]]. The exhibition had an area of 51 hectares. The sample application was filed on June 12, 1980 registering the event as a specialized exposition.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bie-paris.org/main/pages/files/expos/1981-bis.pdf |work= BIE Web Site |title= Superficie y fecha|accessdate= 2007-11-14}}</ref>
The exhibition theme was "hunting, fishing and men in society." The goal was to present the environment through the exhibits of the participating countries, the development of hunting in different parts of the world, showing the interaction between the hunting, fishing and the man in contemporary society, to contribute to maintain and strengthen the culture of hunting<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.bie-paris.org/main/index.php?p=-68&m2=128 |title= Datos |work= BIE Web Site |accessdate= 2007-11-14 |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20071027175213/http://www.bie-paris.org/main/index.php?p=-68&m2=128 |archivedate= 2007-10-27 |df= }}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.bie-paris.org/site/en/1981-plovdiv Official website of the BIE] * [http://www.epo.org/law-practice/legal-texts/official-journal/2016/etc/se4/p219.html European Patent Office]
==See also== *[[List of world's fairs]]

{{Infobox flag | Name = Kent | Article = | Type = | Image = Kent flag.svg | Nickname = Invicta Flag | Morenicks = Invicta Flag of Kent | Use = | Symbol = | Proportion = 3:5 | Adoption = 1605 | Design = Gules, a horse rampant argent | Designer = Traditional }} The '''Flag of Kent''' is the [[flag]] of the [[England|English]] county of [[Kent]]. It features the [[white horse of Kent]] on a red background, a theme used in several other Kent related [[coats of arms]] and logos or symbols. It is sometimes referred to as the '''Invicta Flag''' or '''Invicta Flag of Kent''', after the motto of Kent, ''[[Invicta (motto)|Invicta]]''.{{cite web|title=Kent Invicta Flag|url=http://www.flaginstitute.org/wp/flags/ken/|website=The Flag Institute|accessdate=17 October 2015}} The [[Flag Institute]] note, in the flag's entry on the UK Flags Register that:
This is the traditional flag of Kent, supposedly based on that of [[Horsa]], the Jute. Horsa was the brother of [[Hengest]], who founded the Kingdom of Kent in 449. The first recorded reference is in 1605.
The flag is an adaptation of the traditional arms of Kent to which the quote refers. These arms were attributed anachronistically to the [[Kingdom of Kent]], but used by the Justices of Kent for many years. The arms were officially granted to [[Kent County Council]] on 17 October 1933 (and re-confirmed to its successor in 1975). The flag was accepted by the Flag Institute as that of the historic county on the basis of its traditional use.{{cite web|title=Kent Flag|url=https://britishcountyflags.wordpress.com/2013/08/03/kent-flag/|website=British County Flags|accessdate=17 October 2015|quote=It is reported that a white horse was subsequently used by the Justices of Kent for many years, being generally regarded as the emblem of the former kingdom, turned county. Kent County Council, established in 1889, was formally awarded a grant of arms, bearing the white horse, on 17 October 1933}} ==See also== * [[List of flags of the United Kingdom]] * [[List of English flags]] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Kent}} {{Subnational flags of the United Kingdom}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Kent, Flag of}} [[Category:Kent|Flag]] [[Category:Flags of places in England|Kent]] [[Category:1605 introductions]] [[Category:Red and white flags]] {{England-stub}} {{Europe-flag-stub}}

{{Infobox song contest entry | song = {{flagicon|Finland}} "Fri?" | image = | caption = | year = 1990 | country = Finland | artist = Janne Engblom,
Kim Engblom,
Tina Petersson,
Tina Krause | as = [[Beat (band)|Beat]] | with = | language = Swedish | languages = | composer = Kim Engblom,
Tina Krause,
Janne Engblom | lyricist = Stina Engblom | conductor = Olli Ahvenlaht | place = 21st | points = 8 | lyrics = [http://www.diggiloo.net/?1990fi from Diggiloo Thrush] | prev = La dolce vita | prev_link = La dolce vita (song) | next = Hullu yö | next_link = Hullu yö }} '''"Fri?"''' ("Free?") was the [[Finland|Finnish]] entry in the [[Eurovision Song Contest 1990]], performed in [[Swedish Language|Swedish]] (the first occasion that this language had been used in preference to [[Finnish Language|Finnish]]) by [[Beat (band)|Beat]]. The song was performed 22nd (last) on the night, following [[Cyprus]]' [[Haris Anastasiou]] with "[[Milas Poli]]". At the close of voting, it had received 8 points, placing 21st in a field of 22. The song consists of the band asking the question "which of us are free?" and defining this freedom as "free to think for ourselves". While no answer is ever given, the lyrics strongly imply that nobody experiences this freedom. Beat also recorded the song in Finnish and English, then under the titles "Vapaa?" and "Free" respectively. It was succeeded as [[Finland in the Eurovision Song Contest|Finnish representative]] at the [[Eurovision Song Contest 1991|1991 Contest]] by [[Kaija Kärkinen|Kaija]] with "[[Hullu yö]]". ==References== * [http://www.eurovision.tv/page/history/by-year/contest?event=306 Official Eurovision Song Contest site, history by year] * [http://www.diggiloo.net/?1990fi Lyrics, from Diggiloo Thrush] {{Finland in the Eurovision Song Contest}} {{Eurovision Song Contest 1990}} [[Category:Eurovision songs of Finland]] [[Category:Eurovision songs of 1990]] [[Category:Swedish-language songs]] [[Category:1990 songs]] {{finland-stub}}

{{no footnotes|date=March 2016}} {{Infobox settlement | name = Gmina Nowa Słupia | other_name = Nowa Słupia Commune | settlement_type = [[Gmina]] | total_type = Total | image_flag = | image_shield = Gmina nowa slupia herb.svg | image_map = | subdivision_type = Country | subdivision_name = {{POL}} | subdivision_type1 = [[Voivodeships of Poland|Voivodeship]] | subdivision_name1 = [[Świętokrzyskie Voivodeship|Świętokrzyskie]] | subdivision_type2 = [[Powiat|County]] | subdivision_name2 = [[Kielce County]] | area_total_km2 = 85.94 | population_total = 9691| population_as_of = 2006 | population_density_km2 = auto | coor_pinpoint = Nowa Słupia | coordinates = {{coord|50|51|45|N|21|5|13|E|region:PL|display=inline,title}} | seat = [[Nowa Słupia]] | website = http://www.nowaslupia.pl }} __NOTOC__ '''Gmina Nowa Słupia''' is a rural ''[[gmina]]'' (administrative district) in [[Kielce County]], [[Świętokrzyskie Voivodeship]], in south-central [[Poland]]. Its seat is the village of [[Nowa Słupia]], which lies approximately {{convert|34|km|mi|0}} east of the regional capital [[Kielce]].
The gmina covers an area of {{convert|85.94|km2|sqmi|1}} and, {{As of|2016|December|31|lc=y}}, its total population is 9,559.<ref>{{Citation|title=Population. Size and Structure and Vital Statistics in Poland by Territorial Division in 2016|url=https://stat.gov.pl/download/gfx/portalinformacyjny/pl/defaultaktualnosci/5468/6/21/1/stan_i_struktura_ludno_oraz_ruch_naturalny_w_przekroju_teryt_stan-na-31-12-2016.pdf|year=2017|last1=Znajewska|last2=Stańczak|last3=Cierniak-Piotrowska|last4=Stelmach|last5=Urbanowicz|last6=Kostrzewa|first1=Agnieszka|first2=Joanna|first3=Małgorzata|first4=Karina|first5=Magdalena|first6=Zofia|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180104192529/https://stat.gov.pl/download/gfx/portalinformacyjny/pl/defaultaktualnosci/5468/6/21/1/stan_i_struktura_ludno_oraz_ruch_naturalny_w_przekroju_teryt_stan-na-31-12-2016.pdf|deadurl=no|page=148|place=Warsaw, Poland|publisher=Central Statistical Office|editor-last=Szałtys|editor-first=Dorota|ISSN=2451-2087|accessdate=7 January 2018|archivedate=4 January 2018}}</ref>
The gmina contains part of the [[protected area]] called [[Jeleniowska Landscape Park]].
==Villages== Gmina Nowa Słupia contains the villages and settlements of [[Bartoszowiny]], [[Baszowice]], [[Cząstków, Świętokrzyskie Voivodeship|Cząstków]], [[Dębniak, Świętokrzyskie Voivodeship|Dębniak]], [[Dębno, Gmina Nowa Słupia|Dębno]], [[Hucisko, Gmina Nowa Słupia|Hucisko]], [[Jeleniów, Świętokrzyskie Voivodeship|Jeleniów]], [[Jeziorko, Świętokrzyskie Voivodeship|Jeziorko]], [[Mirocice]], [[Nowa Słupia]], [[Paprocice]], [[Pokrzywianka, Kielce County|Pokrzywianka]], [[Rudki, Kielce County|Rudki]], [[Serwis]], [[Skały, Świętokrzyskie Voivodeship|Skały]], [[Sosnówka, Świętokrzyskie Voivodeship|Sosnówka]], [[Stara Słupia]], [[Trzcianka, Kielce County|Trzcianka]], [[Włochy, Kielce County|Włochy]] and [[Wólka Milanowska]].
==Neighbouring gminas== Gmina Nowa Słupia is bordered by the gminas of [[Gmina Bieliny|Bieliny]], [[Gmina Bodzentyn|Bodzentyn]], [[Gmina Łagów, Świętokrzyskie Voivodeship|Łagów]], [[Gmina Pawłów|Pawłów]] and [[Gmina Waśniów|Waśniów]].
==References== <references />{{Gmina Nowa Słupia}} {{Kielce County}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Gmina Nowa Slupia}} [[Category:Gminas in Świętokrzyskie Voivodeship|Nowa Slupia]] [[Category:Kielce County]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = hajooj kuka | image = Hajooj Kuka.jpg | alt = | caption = hajooj kuka in Mombasa Jan 2015 | birth_name = <!-- only use if different from name --> | birth_date = <!-- {{Birth date and age|1980}}--> | birth_place = Sudan | death_date = <!-- {{Death date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} or {{Death-date and age|death date†|birth date†}} --> | death_place = | nationality = [[Sudan]]ese | other_names = | alma_mater = [[American University of Beirut]], [[San Jose State University]] | occupation = [[Film director|Director]], [[War Correspondent|Reporter]] | years_active = 2004–present | known_for = | notable_works = ''[[Beats of the Antonov]]'' }}
'''Hajooj Kuka''' is the founder of Refugee Club and the director [[Beats of the Antonov]].<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/dec/09/-sp-sudan-music-hajooj-kuka Music of resistance in Sudan's rebel regions]''[[The Guardian]]'', Retrieved 14, 2015.</ref> Kuka was born in Sudan of the Mahas ethnic group, but relocated with his family to the United Arab Emirates. Kuka travels frequently between Nuba Mountains and the Blue Niles for his creative works. He resides in both Sudan and Kenya. Kuka previously worked at Middle East Broadcast Network in Virginia and Shilo Incorporation in New York City as a video editor and post production tech/ editor. He is currently creative director at [http://www.3ayin.com/ 3ayin], a Sudanese Arabic reports of violent conflict occurrence in Sudan.
== Education == Kuka studied Electrical Engineering at [[American University of Beirut]] (AUB) and Digital Design at [[San Jose State University]], California, USA.
== Career == In 2014 his [[Documentary film|documentary]] ''Beats of the Antonov'' on war, music, and identity won the People's Choice Award at [[2014 Toronto International Film Festival]]. Kuka worked on this documentary for two years with the aim of telling a story that worth sharing with the world; a story of resilience and resistance in the face of adversity through music was made over a period of two years with Director Hajooj Kuka residing among the People of the Nuba Mountains in Sudan.<ref>TIFF: [http://www.strictlydocs.com/tag/beats-of-the-antonov/ Beats Bags The Big Prize], ''Strictly Docs'', September 15, 2014.</ref> Through his efforts, Kuka was listed in the ''Foreign Policy Magazine'' as one of the Leading Global Thinkers (Chroniclers category) of 2014.<ref>[http://globalthinkers.foreignpolicy.com/ A World Disrupted: The Leading Global Thinkers of 2014] ''FP'', Retrieved March 1, 2015.</ref>
Aside from the Beats of the Antonov, Kuka's other documentary, [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=I16iN7jfVoE Darfur Skeleton] under his other name (Hisham Hajomar), was based on the agonising reality of the displaced Sudanese in the aftermath of the ruination of the Kondowa forest.<ref>[http://www.darfurskeleton.com/ Darfur's Skeleton] ''Refugee Club'', Retrieved March 1, 2015.</ref> Kuka through his work shows his non-violent resistance ideology by depicting through creative visualisation, the struggle and resistance of the people of Sudan caught in the web of intractable conflicts.
In 2018, Kuka directed his first narrative feature ''[[Akasha (2018 film)|Akasha]]''.
== Activism == Kuka is an active member of [http://www.girifna.com/ GIRIFNA], a non-violent resistance movement in Sudan. Kuka works with various activists in Sudan and in the diaspora for a transformed state of affairs in the country. Despite the non-violence stance, the Sudanese government hunts, tortures and jails Sudanese activists at will and Kuka who has been detained himself, protests their releases.<ref>[http://www.kcl.ac.uk/index.aspx #FreeHassanIshaq: a journalist tortured in detention] ''Girifna'', June 22, 2014.</ref>
Kuka is optimistic that Sudanese resilience and resistance to oppression and injustice will yield a positive outcome in the long run. He envisions a secular country that promotes its various dynamism most especially on culture and identity.<ref>[http://www.upnairobi.com/dt_portfolio/beats-of-the-antonov/ Beats of the Antonov] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402150217/http://www.upnairobi.com/dt_portfolio/beats-of-the-antonov/ |date=2015-04-02 }} ''UP'' February 25, 2015.</ref>
== Other Work == Kuka is also a [[War correspondent|War Correspondent]] (Reporter) in the Nuba Mountains of Sudan.<ref name=TIFF>[http://www.tiff.net/festivals/thefestival/programmes/tiff-docs/beats-of-the-antonov Beats of Antonov] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150123113647/http://www.tiff.net/festivals/thefestival/programmes/tiff-docs/beats-of-the-antonov |date=2015-01-23 }} ''tiff.'', Retrieved February 22, 2015.</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{authority control}}

[[File:Kiss-FM Kobe01n3200.jpg|thumb|200px|Headquarters in [[Kobe]]]] '''Hyogo FM Broadcasting Co. Ltd.''' ([[doing business as|DBA]] '''Kiss-FM KOBE.Co.Ltd''') is an FM radio station in [[Kobe]], [[Hyogo]], [[Japan]].
==Overview== The network was first launched as a relay station of [[FM Oita]] (Air-Radio FM88, [[Oita Prefecture]]) in October, 1990. When it started, it was called as {{nihongo|Hyogo FM radiobroadcast|兵庫エフエムラジオ放送|Hyogo Efuemu Rajio Ho-so-}}. It was an independent station until it joined [[Japan FM Network|JFN]] on April 1, 2003.
Its main broadcast frequency is at 89.9 MHz, with an output of 1 kW and transmits from the [[Mount Rokkō|Rokko mount]] range where reception is possible for most of the Kansai area.
There was a satellite studio, now closed, in the [[America Mura]] of [[Osaka]].
== program == *4 seasons *Kiss Music Presenter
==See also== [[List of radio stations in Japan]]
==External links== *{{ja icon}}[http://www.kiss-fm.co.jp Kiss-FM KOBE]
{{JFN}}
[[Category:Radio in Japan]] [[Category:Media in Kobe]] [[Category:Radio stations established in 1990]]

97.1 MHz (Busan) [[#Other Provinces|...more]] | format = [[K-Pop]], [[Classical music]], [[Entertainment]], [[News]] | owner = [[Korean Broadcasting System|KBS]] | sister_stations = [[KBS Radio 1]],
[[KBS Radio 3]],
[[KBS 1FM|KBS Classic FM]],
[[KBS 2FM|KBS Cool FM]] | website = [http://www.kbs.co.kr/radio/2radio kbs.co.kr/radio/2radio] | webcast = [http://radio.kbs.co.kr/player_kong/player.html?title=KBS%202Radio%20On-Air&type=live&ch%3D22%26url%3D Listen Live] }} '''KBS Radio 2''' is a [[K-Pop]], [[Classical music]], [[Entertainment]] and [[news]] station owned by the [[Korean Broadcasting System]], almost equivalent to [[DWQZ|979 Home Radio]] and [[DWFT|104.3 FM2]] in the [[Philippines]], [[BBC Radio 2]] in the [[United Kingdom]], [[Radio 2 (Belgium)|VRT Radio 2]] in Flanders, [[Belgium]] and [[VivaCité|RTBF VivaCité]] in [[Wallonia]], [[Belgium]]. Its transmission hours are from 4:53 AM to next day at 3:00 AM daily. The station is also known for being the most powerful FM radio station in [[South Korea]]. == Stations == === Seoul, Incheon, Gyeonggi Province === {| class="wikitable" |- ! Callsign !! Frequency !! Power (㎾) !! Transmitter Location |- | HLSA-AM || AM 603㎑ || 500㎾ || Namyang |- | HLSA-SFM || FM 106.1㎒ || 25㎾ || Gwanaksan |} === Other Provinces === * Chuncheon : FM 98.7 MHz * Wonju : FM 100.5, 88.1 MHz * Gangneung : FM 102.1 MHz, FM 106.7 MHz, FM 103.9 MHz * Daejeon : FM 100.9 MHz * Cheongju : FM 90.9 MHz * Jeonju : FM 92.9 MHz * Gwangju : FM 95.5 MHz * Mokpo : FM 88.1 MHz * Suncheon : FM 102.7 MHz, FM 100.9 MHz, FM 106.7 MHz * Daegu : FM 102.3 MHz, AM 558 kHz * Gimcheon : FM 88.9 MHz * Ulleung Island : FM 92.1 MHz * Busan : FM 97.1 MHz, FM 99.5 MHz * Changwon : FM 106.1 MHz * Jeju : FM 91.9 MHz, FM 89.7 MHz, FM 92.7 MHz == History == * 1934 - Kyeongsong Broadcasting JODK 603 kHz Started broadcasting. * 1947 - Kyeongsong Broadcasting Closed. * 1970 - KBS Drama Radio 666 kHz HLSA Started broadcasting. * 1972 - Frequency Moved to 603 kHz. * 1977 - KBS Radio 2 reformated from Drama to Popular music. * November 9, 1980 - KBS 2Radio FM repeater 106.1MHz Launched becoming [[South Korea]]'s Third FM station. * December 1, 1980 - Renamed as '''KBS-FM'''. along with the launch of [[KBS Radio 3]], [[KBS Cool FM|KBS Radio 4]] (Now Cool FM Formerly TBC Radio), KBS Radio 5 (Now [[SBS Love FM]] Formerly KBS Radio Seoul and DBS) and [[KBS 1FM|KBS Stereo]] (Now Classic FM). * October 20, 2003 - KBS Radio 2 Renamed as Happy FM. Reformated as an entertainment radio station for the middle aged. * March 3, 2005 - Viewable Radio (BORA) Broadcast launched. * 2013 - Returned as KBS-FM Reformated back again as a popular music radio station. == See also == * [[KBS Radio 1]] * [[KBS Radio 3]] * [[HLQL-FM]] * [[MBC FM4U]] * [[Traffic Broadcasting System]] * [[Far East Broadcasting Company]] == References == * http://english.kbs.co.kr/ChannelInfo/Radio/index.html * http://www.kbs.co.kr/radio/happyfm * http://kong.kbs.co.kr/live_player/channelMini.php?id=KBSID&channel=12 {{coord missing|South Korea}} [[Category:Korean Broadcasting System radio networks|Radio 2]] [[Category:Radio stations in South Korea]] [[Category:Chinese-language radio stations]] [[Category:Korean-language radio stations]] [[Category:Vietnamese-language radio stations]] [[Category:Radio stations established in 1980]] [[Category:Chinese popular culture]] [[Category:South Korean popular culture]] {{Asia-radio-station-stub}}
